I also recommend the mini sliders - the lamb and pork ones are awesome - and the chicken satay salad is a good healthy alternative. 


So yeah, I guess I love this place because they serve food until REALLY REALLY late, the food is good quality and there are some interesting specials.

Keep the Yelp deals coming!
author: E-dough R.

description:
I hate to give such a bad review to one of my neighborhood bars but:

I went to get brunch this morning and ordered their version of eggs benedict. While waiting for my food to be prepared I saw one of the cooks drop an english muffin on the floor mat (the ones they hose off out on the sidewalk to clean) then pick it back up and put it in the toaster. I politely informed the waitress and she had the cook throw it out and make a new one.....in the same toaster. Sorry but this is not good enough. We left. I won't be back. This is simply unsanitary and disgusting. Those mats are black with grease and dirt and I've seen them hose them off outside on the filthy sidewalk. The same sidewalk that often has vomit, fecal matter, and all manner of mission grossness. I'm appalled. 
THis place has been very hit or miss over the last 7 years that I've lived here and this is really my last straw. The waitress was very sweet, she always is. Unfortunately this isn't enough to make up for the unsanitary activity. I'm just glad I had a view of the kitchen.
author: Dave F.

description:
OK, I have a really hard time complaining about a place that serves up a bunch of free grub and booze for their 10 year anniversary. Also, I'm looking sheepishly at my feet while I type this e-mail (figuratively) since I normally get stuck at the Lone Palm without making it across the street to this place. Although I still love the LP, this place also kicks ass.

Nifty SF-style Irish bar. Does that mean lots of naked leprachauns? Alas, no...but its all the good parts of Ireland without the crapiness. The food is a tasty spin on bar food - super delish samosas, beef sliders, and I *loved* the scotch eggs (they are pretty much breaded up, deep fried eggs. *gorgeous* I know!). Nothing fancy, but everything was really well balanced spice wise...like everything you want in bar food (in other words, its good even before you get tanked!)

Drinks ain't too shabby either - you've got your obligatory Guniness and yadda yadda, but they do make some tastiness known as the Ginger Mule. You. Must. Get one. It tastes like a spin on a whiskey giner but a lot more refreshing. So delish.

Service peeps are nice, and are cool to chit chat with over the bar. Crowd is pretty chill and relaxed. In general, a great place to grab some drinks on a chill weeknight, or a place to hang out during a nice sunny weekend day on one of the outdoor tables! Yah baby!
author: Sean C.

description:
If you want a good glass of wine or pint of beer it's generally pretty mellow and has a relaxing environment. You can actually hear your friends talking. 

I always enjoy my food but my complaint is if you go for brunch you are going to wait ages to eat. We've done it around 10 times and it's always the same. Make sure you're not starving when you get there...or at least have a snack first.
author: Juliann B.

description:
As a Scotsman living in San Francisco my expectations for a full Irish/Scottish/ hangover breakfast are high.

On a Saturday or Sunday morning before 11 Liberites will quickly serve you a delicious authentic full plate of traditional goodness.  

You will roll home full & happy but probably still not with any clearer idea about the last part of yesterday evening....PAIX
author: angus c.

description:
This place rocks.

What I look for in a bar:

1. Friendly staff
2. Friendly people
3. Beer poured all the way to the top of my pint

This place meets all 3 and I enjoyed my Boddington's and conversation with staff and regulars thoroughly.
author: Jim B.

description: Where's da beef. Right here baby. Been here twice. Enjoyed it both times. I had a burger last week. And I must say it was one hell of a good burger. I don't eat burgers much anymore. But when I do I really do appreciate when they are good. The sweet potato fires just made my day to be honest. It is a nice neighborhood bar and restaurant.
author: Nichole S.

description: Friendly, cool bartenders, great selection.  Chill vibe.  Great pub!
author: A S.

description: I am not a bar person; this is a review of their restaurant.  Eating at The Liberties is always fun for the unique food items.  I love their brunch!  The Irish potato pancakes are a winner as are their cottage pie and sweet potato fries.  They even have black & white pudding (if you're into that sort of thing.)  Service is always friendly.  I love it here.
author: Mark O.

description:
What you think of this place says a lot about you.  They've been around forever and you know you've walked past a million times.  Rather than go into my usual social commentary here, let me just say you should just stop in and check it out for yourself.   and i'll leave the social commentary at that...  

The pub.  I like it.  Chill spot to watch the tail end of the world series, even though the damn yanks won again.  Only damn thing worse than the yankees are yankee fans... unless you're over 60 or something.  For the rest of you johnny come lately's, I mean, real creative there buddy with your stellar sports team.   AND you're not even from nyc?  What a dumb-bag.  But I digress.

With pricey but good food and cold draft beer.  They actually had the cleanest tasting Trumer I've had in this city. Next time i'll get a pitcher of guinness - if they'll do that in pitchers - and see if they really do keep lines clean or if the Trumer was a fluke.  I'd have gone with the whiskey flights this evening but their selections were completely unexciting, except for the last, most expensive combo which had a macallan 18 and some "..angie", ...fiddich" something or other that looked enticing. The rest of the flights just seem to be paying too much for too little of nothing special... johhny red, neat?  i mean, come on.  And I'm no whiskey snob.  I like my jim beam just fine, but make it fun, you know?  maybe pair it with a jim beam black, and the gentleman's jack.  work for it, damn it.

They have rotating evening specials daily, but note to broke ass people, their happy hour ends early, at 6pm. 

Still, I'd have given full five stars if their "buffalo" wings were actually buffalo wings rather than bbq wings.  They were pretty tasty for bbq wings, but note to the chef, owner, menu author: You just can't do that.  You're bound to ruffle some feathers.  Ha!  And unrequited cravings can get ugly when she has to go down the hill to phoenix to get some real buffalo wings afterwards. 

Still, grade inflation for somehow managing to keep the "mission" out, a much needed respite at times from all the post-punk 20somethings following eachother to try to find their unique identity or whatever.  I think its maybe the $7 dollar fries (well, fine, they were sweet potato, and they were good) or the big ass wooden podium for the hostess effectively blocking the doorway...
  
oh yeah, service was excellent. Our guy was helpful, efficient, and seemed genuinely friendly. 

See what I'm saying?  I think I'm becoming that a- -hole.  people who like this place talk about the cleanliness of taplines... and parse chicken wings.... and did I really say "and you're not even from nyc?" somewhere up there?  Yeah, I'd kick my own balls too sometimes...
author: Nikki F.

description:
My friends and I decided to have a game night (nerd alert) at Liberties and experienced good food, service and one of the best Irish Coffees I have had in a long time. Good place to bring a board game too. 
-Thanks.
author: Alejandro M.

description:
First time at The Liberties = LIKE 

I'm still deciding if it was it the awesome sliders or the sunny day? The Makers Mark Old Fashions or the lovely bartenders? The sweet potato fries or the chill crowd? 

Regardless, the place has a hospitable vibe that is intimate but not cramped, a big darkwood bar with lots of natural light, outdoor seating, and pub food that is a step above. 

I hear their brunch rocks.
author: Alona G.

description:
This is one of the best spots in town to get a good pint of Guinness. If you've had a good pint of Guinness before, you'll know that only about 1 in 20 Irish pubs have them.

The food is good Irish pub grub and decent burgers. Also, food served until 1am.
author: Triston I.

description:
I go to liberties at least once a week... my toddler LOVES the sweet potato fries and the pasta.  I love everything else!  The staff are so personable and friendly and I always feel like I am at home.  The bloody mary's are ridiculous!

Fish and chips will knock your socks off, not to mention Taco Tuesday!
author: suzanne k.

description:
Good bar but too expensive. 

Wish I could give it 3.5 stars. Better then any and all three starers but just not a true four because of the prices. But I did get locked out of my house once and was able to easily kill a couple of hours. 

Plenty of TVs, cool bartenders and decent food. Smithwick's on tap always gets me and they had Kilkenny for awhile. Try to hit it up for happy hour or make sure you want to watch a game that's on. If not, Lone Palm is right across the street.
author: Michael C.

description:
Went here for birthday dinner. Very small place but pretty good food for pub fare. Nice atmosphere, very clean and fun. I would eat here again. Was able to try:
- Chicken Satay (slightly better than average 3/5)
- Crab Cakes (Standout item, if I rated on this alone I would give it 4.5 out of 5)
- Sweet potato fries (yummy, hard to mess up 4/5)
- Potato Pancakes with Smoked Salmon (3.5 out of 5)
author: Talina M.

description:
Kinda expensive but a really cute little spot to grab a bev and chill out with some pals.  

I went with my boyfriend and our good pal for the Super Bowl.  Man, this place was packed!!  We got there about an hour and a half before the game started and got one of the last tables in the bar.  We had a great little hightop right smack in the middle of the bar area.  We snagged a pitcher of Lagunitas from our totally sweet server Annette and settled in for the game.  

Unfortunately, as you all know, the Niners lost.  And that was really super sucky.  BUT alas, our time at The Liberties was pretty awesome.  

Food was pretty tasty.  We shared hot wings (they also have sweet wings), the beet salad, and I had fish and chips.  The wings were really tasty.  They were spicy but not over-the-top burn-your-face-off spicy, and they were packed full of yummy spicy flavor.  The beet salad isn't something I'd ever order off a menu, as I'm not totally crazy about beets, but the ladies at the table next to ours had a couple and they looked awesome.  Dark greens (I really don't think you can call it a salad if it's made with iceberg lettuce), beets, grapefruit, nuts - yum yum yum.  Totally delicious.  Really nicely dressed.  And then my fish and chips - totally awesome.  A little on the pricey side at $15 or $16 for fish and chips, but three giant pieces of fish and a whole ton of fries?  Yes please.  I should note that we'd also gotten some sweet potato fries earlier in the evening and they were ridiculously good.  Ohhhh man, I loveeee sweet potato fries.  I want some right now . . . 

The staff was all really friendly, from the woman who greeted us at the door to our server to the food runner who went out of his way to grab plates and silver for us to share our first course.  

I knocked one star for how expensive this spot is (though certainly not out of line for a really hip spot in the city) and for the fact that they only have one bathroom.  By the end of the game, there was a line several people long waiting to use the restroom.  

I hear they have a pretty awesome brunch on Sundays and I can't wait to come back to check it out!
author: Kate H.

description:
Liberties is a surprising little Irish gem! I've driven by this place a few times before actually checking it out and was pleased to find that it is more than just a bar. It has a great atmosphere, quaint outside seating and a decent menu.

Check it out! And try their samosas!
author: Lauren T.

description:
We got mussels, bangers and mash, cottage pie, and a steak and fries--all decent, but not exactly noteworthy. I had a Smithwick's (apparently my drink of choice these days). The girls in our party commented that the watermelon mojito tasted like cough syrup, but the grapefruit cocktail (whatever it was called) was pretty good.

The service was very, very slow. In fact, I noticed the table next to us got served first even though we arrived much earlier. Too bad, I really wanted to like this place because it felt quite cozy. Maybe just a couple of beers and fries next time...
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I need to drown my sorrows on my last night in SF and the Liberties (which I initially thought was, "Libertines") was in walking distance from where I was staying. 

It's got a really nice vibe with a young-ish, attractive crowd and I'm loving the choice of tunes playing in background. Everyone was really friendly (staff and crowd) but as it got busier, the service slowed down. However, I must say, Jasmine, the bartender is really sweet. Love her. 

Luckily, a couple of really nice gents bought me drinks, but I paid for one and food (great fried calamari), so I can understand how the tab could add up.
author: Kim J.

description:
As a place that serves late night, I feel like I should give it a higher rating on that alone.  The Liberties has saved me from many nights of pizza again because it is the one other thing I know that's actually open and convenient to my house.  Also the brunch is pretty damn good, even though I hardly ever make it over there for it.

That said, I just can't get all jazzed up about The Liberties.  The food is okay. The servers are okay (although they do have one that is fabulous). I have been hung up on several times when I wanted to place a take out order.  It's just hard to muster much excitement for it.

I'm settling for three stars because I really do love the fact that they serve late and save me from pizza, yet again.
author: Rebecca H.

description: A nice neighborhood bar with good drinks and outdoor seating. The atmosphere is relaxed and the waitstaff and bartenders are friendly. I'll probably be back again when I'm in the area.
author: Sheila T.

description: Nice place to sit down and meet up with someone. It  has a nice intimate vibe. I didnt get to try their food. Maybe next time.
author: Lidia Z.

description: This place is a great sports bar.  How could anyone write a negative review about Liberties? This is my spot for the simple pleasures in life...watching Giants Baseball, drinking good beer, and hipster watching.  Fantastic!
author: Cameron Y.

description:
I was less than impressed with The Liberties. We stopped in here since we were down the street, and saw a few groups of people eating lunch outside. A quick glance at the menu and we walked in. No one came to seat us, no sign of servers except the bartender who did not give us a second glance. After noticing this we sat ourselves at a table with a menu. We also had to flag down the waitress to take our order. The trend here: service sucks, and it wasn't even friendly or apologetic. 

We split the cesar salad and crab cakes appetizer. I guess the star is for the crab cakes- really good but there was only two of them. For the price... I don't think so. The salad was super dry and we had to ask for extra dressing.

The only reason I'd return is to try the bar. Maybe.
author: Bekah L.

description:
Adam and I wanted to meet for a beer after work, and we just wanted to grab a slice, but parking around 16th and Valencia was such a fuckshow that we abandoned that idea. He suggested having a drink at Liberties, and I said sure, I've never been there. We ended up ordering dinner - and what a massive mistake that was. $20 steak and $14 fish and chips, the steak was like a shoe and the fish tasted like the newspaper it should have been wrapped in. Incredibly, the tab was more than $100, and we both left feeling worse than when we walked in. What a joke. 

Lastly, why, why, why is the place packed with happy Friday-evening diners? I mean, sure, have a pint, no worries, but why in the fuck would you eat crappy pub food for triple the fair price???

I say fuck this, fuck that sort of neighborhood disgrace. Never again.
author: Bowen D.

description: I often dined here on Monday nights because of the atmosphere--they had a fantastic pub quiz night, but just got a message that it's been canceled. So I have no reason to suffer thru their greasy food and spotty customer service any more.
author: Babs P.

description:
Not so long ago this was a pretty regular part of my rotation on weekday and sometimes weekend nights.  It's hard to remember how that came to be, but I think it had a lot to do with the fact that The Liberties is usually not nearly as packed or loud as other bars within walking distance of my place.  

Yet despite many, many trips, I can't say that Liberties is a place that is memorable beyond the convenience of getting there and getting a table.  The service is almost always slow even when the place is virtually empty.  The wait staff is usually not particularly friendly... except a couple of guys who are awkwardly over the top.  If you're not getting food, I really recommend just ordering at the bar.   

The food is pretty decent overall although perhaps a bit overpriced.  The prices make apparent that The Liberties has aspirations to be Irish 'cuisine' instead of just glorified bar food.  They're half way there.  Kitchen is open late, which is a plus.

In the end, if you're not looking for food and if it's not too crowded across the street at Lone Palm (and it probably will be), I would probably recommend going there instead of The Liberties.  On the other hand, if you don't mind sitting around for a while to get your order taken, your drinks served, and your check, and if you'd prefer a place where there are windows to look out onto 22nd & Guerrero, The Liberties isn't so bad.
author: Josh C.

description: Really hit the spot. We had the farmers omelet and the bacon avocado omelet. Tasty.
author: Gundersaurus X.

description:
Bloody good brunch for this carnie. Literally.
WARNING: this review is meat-intensive.

Completely by a chance glance at a beautiful benedict at an outside table, we opted to stop our brunch commute one block short of hip.

I had the traditional Irish breakfast. Traditional or not, it was delicious with an abundance of crispy potatoes, grilled tomato, two eggs and THREE meats: 3 links sweet sausage; a sizzling slab of Irish bacon (like ham, but less salty, more smoky and crisp on the edges); and two pieces each-Black + White Puddings. The black (blood) pudding was just dry enough to soak up some of the egg yolk into some sort of succulent, ultra iron-rich superfood. The sweet/salty/dry/juicy/smoky goodness haunts me two days later. In best possible way.

Our gracious server anticipated our every need, bringing fresh glasses of coffee and Arnold Palmers every time the levels dropped below a third full.

To my UK-born, Scotch-drinking, pudding-browning, euchre-slamming grandma (God rest her soul) - I get it now.
author: Andy R.

description:
Quite possibly the best veggie burger I've had in San Francisco.

I know! Who woulda thunk it? The Irish ain't exactly veggie burger people, what with their sausages and their bacon and their corned beef (and of COURSE I mean Irish-Americans with that one, so don't start PM'ing me about how they don't eat corned beef in Ireland). But the Liberties' veggie burger was REALLY good. 

Now, I would have made this a 3-star review because the service was kinda slow, even though SuperBF and I were the first people in when they opened for brunch on a Sunday. And the waitress who served us needed to put more clothes on. Like a LOT more clothes. Not just because it was cold and rainy out, but because I really didn't want her leaning over our table consistently when her shirt was so low-cut I could see her navel. That tinkered with my appetite and made it difficult for me to enjoy said delicious-if-slightly-enigmatic-perfect-veggie-burger-made-by-Irish-carnivores. 

But, her slowness actually worked to our advantage. Because SuperBF had just bought a CrackBerry: a device who's operating system was causing him a considerable amount of angst that we simply HAD to address during our meal. So we needed the extra time. 

Indecent waitress: I'm giving you a freebie on that one. I'll be back to the Liberties again for a hungover veggie burger brunch because it really was that good, but I don't know if I'll bring SuperBF unless you put some more clothes on. Because he ended up returning the CrackBerry and he won't have anything to keep him distracted...

AND MAMA NEEDS A GOOD VEGGIE BURGER WHEN SHE'S HAD TOO MUCH OF HER SAUCE.
author: Lisa T.

description:
We missed out on eating Irish grub on St. Paddy's Day.......
so maybe that has something to do with waking up craving to have breakfast at Liberties. It was a little rough being there first thing in the morning with the super bleach scent still lingering throughout the joint at least I know they're doing their best to sanitize the place. I had the 'Liberty Shire' minus the hollandaise sauce that seems to come on everything, I don't know if it's an Irish tradition or just a Liberties tradition. The wet brunch bar was not so good. Good, fast, friendly service.
author: Paulette B.

description:
We went here this afternoon for a late lunch/early dinner and a couple of drinks. Although I'm married to an Irishman, for some reason we'd only been here once before. Turns out it's a very good bar--I liked it alot.

I had the veggie burger, which was extremely tasty. My husband rated his burger at 6 out of 10, but he's pretty picky, so take that with a grain of salt. It wasn't packed inside at 4pm on a Sunday, but there were a good few people in there, most of them Irish. The bartender, Gerry, was great--loved him! He was funny and nice and gave me little tastes of all the mixed drinks he was making for everyone else (we were the only ones sitting at the bar). He makes a mean "nuts and berries," which is Chambord, Sambuca and cream, I believe. Mmm. 

A woman who we were pretty sure was the owner came in while we were there and I've heard not-so-great things about the way she treats her employees (I'm friends with a girl who used to work here), which was subtly backed up during our trip there today. So I've subtracted one star for that bad behavior. Otherwise, good bar!
author: kelly m.

description:
gotta be the best irish breakie in town - believe me i've tried them all.
Anytime i feel like i am missing the green isle,off to liberties i go, order
my full irish, all the black and white, rashers and bangers imported from home and to top it off heinz baked beans.
I wash it down with barrys irish tea all the way from Cork city- the real capitol langers-  and i just have enough room for a pint of guinness or two.......... I know a good sausage and pudding when i get one, i worked in Galtee for a couple of summers.
All this fare goes hand in hand with the relaxed friendly atmosphere here, and they even have real footie on the telly. Makes me feel right at home.
author: wayne s.

description:
Corned Beef Hash.

It's a dish that used to scare the hell out of me when it came from a can and had a fried egg on top of it via my grandma's kitchen, but later turned into a happy smile on my face when it was re-introduced to me as a hangover cure at LA's Fiddler's Bistro. Today though, I don't really know what to think of it after trying it last weekend at The Liberties. 

On the whole, it was pretty good. I found the corned beef to be a bit gummy and chewy, which I understand is tough to avoid in corned beef, but I know it's possible, so slight deduction for that. The eggs were perfect and deelish. The potatoes were very good and the portion was enough to fill my hungry belly and make me happy. But that was really about it. There weren't any fireworks of the "come back soon" variety going off. There wasn't any strong desire to ask "what is in this dish?!?!?" And there really wasn't a big draw to recommend it to anyone, but it was okay.

What I did like more was my Bloody Mary. It was tasty, spicy and deelish. Granted, it was no Eddie's BM Special at Elixir on Sunday, but it hit the spot and helped my friend and I erase our hangovers and dammit, do you need anything more?
author: Stephy S.

description:
I first came for a birthday get-together in the dark-wooded, dim-lit pub on a rainy Saturday evening, and I found it instantly warm and inviting. Maybe it was the rain, maybe it wasn't. It was very different from the usual Irish pubs that overdo it with Guinness and soccer paraphernalia all over. Nice selection of bar food -- calamari, quesadillas, buffalo wings and samosas, so it will heal your happy-hour hungries.

I don't think I'd come for a proper meal, but it's a good place to chat with a friend over snacks and drinks.
author: Tara R.

description:
This is a great place!  Friendly, fun, good value and a nice place to relax and have some laughs.  We go there often (monthly) and the quality is good and the specials are delightful.  

If you like Dublin and the more modern style of pubs one finds there, then you will love this not over the top Irish place.  if you are looking for top cuisine then this in NOT the place but if a very good supper with some cocktails/beers/wines etc suit your fancy, then give this place a try!
author: M P.

description:
'Uh, isn't french onion soup supposed to have cheese and or a crouton?'
'Is this...I mean... you didn't....(sigh)....You MICROWAVED my fucking pork chop didn't you?! That can be the only explanation for this rubbery, white-hot pig-flesh.'
One star for location.
One star John Powers Irish Whiskey and a decent pint of guinness.
author: Big S.

description:
I didn't have any food so my review is just of the drinks.

They mix wonderful cocktails. I enjoyed The French Kiss especially but I pissed off the waiter by ordering three of them throughout the evening (plus two other girly drinks).

Oh well, his hot accent made up for the anger.
author: Vikki P.

description: Cuzzo brought me here. Great food and yummy happy hour cocktails. We each ordered 3 of the special tea cocktail.  I think it was a Wednesday...
author: Joan M.

description:
For shame!  I live a scant half block from the Liberties, and it is one of my standby places.  This is why it is a shame.

Why you may ask, dear Yelpers?  Well, for one, the last time I went (the weekend of June 24th, for brunch), I ordered the crab cake benedict.  Now, I have to have eggs benedict whenever I dine on the weekends.  I was surprised to discover that one of my components of this delight was missing: The English muffin.

NOW, that said, were we banning English muffins that day?  Have the Catholics really "had it up to here" with the Protestants that my English muffin had been discarded like IRA weaponry and materiel?  Well, I asked the waiter just that.  Nary an apology was to be found from his Anglican lips.

He said that he'd find out what happened.  30 minutes later, and no muffin to be found, nor the waiter, we paid our bill and left an equivalent tip to the waiter's reaction.

The Liberties is a love hate relationship of sorts.

Sometimes you can go in there and have a killer meal.  The next time you arrive, the meal may kill you (such as the raw chicken presented to my roommate).  It's Irish roulette presented in a faux-Irish setting.

Although I do have to admit, the mixed drinks are really good.

Long and short--if you're going to drink, this may be the place for you.  If you're going to eat, hold on to that roulette wheel tight.  If the food and service were to improve (such as actually hunting down that English muffin and bringing it to the table, no matter how late, that would have made a world of difference--like the waiter cared a LITTLE bit), I may be capable of increasing my rating. 

However, given the track record there, nary a new star will be seen on this posting.
author: David S.

description:
I live close enough to the Liberties to walk down there for brunch, but just far enough that I can justify driving. God apparently agreed with my justification and gave me a spot literally across the street this Sunday.

BF and I wandered in for a late brunch and were the only customers in there, so service wasn't a problem. I had a really delicious bloody mary to kick things off, and ordered the potato pancake with smoked salmon and poached eggs on top. Dee-lish-us. Special shoutout to the amazing yukon gold hash browns. Oh, yukon golds, is there anything you can't do? You shame all other potatoes with your superior deliciousness. I bet russets really hate your ass. 

Awesome brunch, but this is also a good watering hole. I've always had a good time here for drinks, and this is also the bar where a Chicago couple once tried to flatter me into a threesome with them, so you know, maybe you'll get lucky? 

Minus one star because it gets crowded on weekend nights with spillover from the Lone Palm, and also because the bathroom handle is tricky and I once had to do the embarrassed, half-squat, knees together "I'm in here!!!!" frantic panicked yell when a guy opened the door on me.
author: Leah S.

description:
While waiting for friends to get to the Lone Palm, I joined some locals at Liberties.  It's a nice little pub in the Mission.  The place was not crowded and we ordered our beers and were promptly served.

I didn't get to try the food, but it sounds like I wouldn't be disappointed.  The waitress and bartender were certainly more attentive than the bartender at the Lone Palm.  

I spent an interesting evening at Liberties...  I was hanging out with a local who had her dad, literally, in tow.  Her dad was in a box; it was his birthday, but he passed on 2 years ago.
author: Annalynn C.

description:
I was here with a large group of people, to watch Obama's acceptance speech for the presidential nomination.  I'm actually quite critical of Mr. Obama (yes, I'm black) and his ability to affect real change, so I'm not sure how I will exercise my vote in November, but I was thoroughly moved by witnessing such a historical moment, while being surrounded by such hopeful and inspired people that night.  It was a beautiful experience.

Unfortunately, I think we had a few too many people at Liberties, than they would have liked.  Although I appreciate them agreeing to host our political happy hour, the servers were quite annoyed with the fact that they couldn't easily move through the crowd to deliver drinks and food, but the areas they were trying to get through were prime television watching real estate.  What to do...what to do.. Fortunately, things seemed to settle down a bit when the speech started.  

Drinks were relatively easy to get and mixed well, but the food took a REALLY long time to come out (this was after the party had disbanded) and it was quite on the bland side.  I ordered fish and chips and left half my order on my plate when leaving the bar.  My friend ordered the curry and rice dish and was underwhelmed.  Food is definitely not their forte, and I'm make sure to remember that, if I'm ever here again.
author: LaSha G.

description:
Ugh...I wouldn't keep coming here if I didn't live so incredibly close-by and the fact that it's open late for dinner.  Today, nothing else at my little intersection was open on Memorial Day Monday...

Tonight I shared 3 items:
The Salmon Avocado Rolls - which I believe were actually filled with canned tuna and a whole lot of sun-dried tomatoes.  But they were fried and anything fried with a nice dipping sauce can go a long way.
Spinach Salad w Chicken - this had zero taste what-so-ever.  Just that nice after-spinach feeling in your mouth.  The chicken seemed like it was leftovers from last night's dinner and the milky dressing did nothing to moisten the salad let alone flavor it.
Mussels - eh...

If and when I am desperate enough to return to this place, I need to remember that this is no posh pub.  I'll go for the garden burger or something that can be dressed up with mustard and ketchup.

Oh, the wait staff are almost always challenged.  Regardless or time or day they only seem to have one waiter.
author: Nicole N.

description: good place to go for a chill night. there are several small tables in the front and there's a small seating area with booths towards the back. the one thing i really didn't like was that the bar was really understaffed. even though it was a friday night, there was only ONE bartender. since she was focusing on getting an order for a whole group at a table done, i literally waited 15-20 minutes of "be with you RIGHT after this!"s for my dark and stormy. she was really nice and apologetic though, and i felt bad for her being the only one working on the drink orders. the variety of the cocktails is pretty good and they even have dessert ones that are made with ice cream! if i wasn't so full already i definitely would have tried one. there's a good food/snack selection too, in case you get the drunk munchies
author: Stephanie C.

description:
The Liberties is one of my neighborhood restaurants. I eat there almost once a week, frequently on Wednesdays. The service is excellent. The atmosphere friendly. The drinks are great and reasonable. The 'burgers are among the best in town. I usually choose a salad, but when I splurge, their sweet potato fries are 'out of this world.' Occasionally I get a steak with a delicious peppercorn sauce. But they have a full menu. I've had the pork chop, pasta, chicken sandwich. 

Occasionally I've been there for weekend brunch. Everything is excellent. My dogs prefer it when I sit outside with them. But sometimes I tie them up outside and sit inside by the window. On the whole they're pretty good. They enjoy going there almost as much as I do!
author: Rob B.

description:
Went there for breakfast today, and had a great meal.  I had the corn beef hash with poached eggs, and my husband had the eggs benny with their Irish bacon.  Mine was $9 and his was $10.  They both were great.  He raved about the Irish Bacon, the eggs were poached perfectly, and the service was great.  We were sitting away from the bar, and the waitress made sure to check up on us and keep the coffee cups full.  I can't wait to go back and try other breakfasts.  

Skip the crowd at other more expensive neighborhood breakfast spots and check them out.  I just wish they had breakfast on weekdays.
author: C H.

description:
Foreshame.  I have tried so hard to like Liberties; it has so much potential!   Liberties'  location in between the Mission and Noe Valley is ideal and the ambiance seems great at night, with the candle-lit tables hiding the (euro) football jerseys that grace the walls.  I embrace my Irish heritage and try to recruit others to do the same (that is....embrace my heritage). So what's the problem?

I don't think  my grandmothers (God rest their souls) would be to happy  if they knew about the monstrosity  that is Liberties Irish breakfast (Actually I think  took my Grams to eat here once and that's a direct quote).  The food here is rubbish.  I've come here for lunches, brunches, drunk munchies, you name it.  Even stranger, if you come later at night you can't tell if you're in a bar, or a restaurant that's about to close.  The staff here is not particularly perky, especially in the aforementioned situation.  When the place is empty at 11, I have never even felt comfortable stickin around for a nightcap!    Writing this review makes me sad because I really WANT to like Liberties!  But seriously, an "Irish Pub" that serves a "Mudslide martini"....?
author: Kerry D.

description:
Met up with a big group on Monday night for a good-bye party for a friend moving away. We were able to move a bunch of bar-top small tables together. Food (fish and chips, potato pancake with salmon) was delicious and came out quick from the kitchen. We were surprised that they were still serving up grub at 11pm, saving us the trip to grab a burrito down the road.  Pretty good beer selection - Stella and the usual selection of beer from the isles on tap, plus a range in bottles too. It looked like there was only one bartender/waiter but he was quick and seemed to be able to be everywhere at once while also being super friendly and entertaining. 

Classier than most places we usually gather at a few blocks away on Mission and Valencia.
author: Mindy S.

description:
Had their full irish breakfast here one morning. Came with both white and black pudding which is a must! but didn't come with toast! How can you serve beans without toast- it's something you need to order on the side. There were many options on the menu as well, I liked this place because it wasn't crowded in any form or manner. Definitely very chill. 

I walked by late one night on a Monday night, and thought it would be a cool place for first dates- not busy, candles, yet- it's a pub/bar where you can get drinks, snacks and food with the tv in the background to provide you with some distraction or topic of conversation if things get too quite.
author: Len K.

description:
I was just at Liberties with my roommate and had the worst experience i have ever had at a restaurant (which led is to the ER).

Three of us were at a table filled with plates, glasses and a freshly lit candle (everything completely crammed). My roommate went to put his napkin down when it lit on fire from the candle. He grabbed it to put it out so nothing else caught fire and severely burned his thumb.

As he ran outside the hostest ran up and said, "what the f*ck are you doing?"  Then when he gets back to the table and sees his hand she stutters and i tell her to get him a bag of ice.

We sit there a while longer and finish our drinks and wait far too long for our bill. The bill comes and no discount, no visit from a manager, no compensation whatsoever (any one would have at least shown some concern.)

After five hours in the ER for a tetanus shot, bandage and recommendation to a hand surgeon for later in the week (scarring ruin mobility on his thumb) we are finally home. . I will NEVER visit Liberties again. This was the worst customer service i have ever seen (I worked in bars and restaurants for 6 years and I would have never reacted this way).
author: Chris H.

description:
My boyfriend and our friend went here last night for some after hours festivities. We were greeted with a smile when we walked into this very well aired bar.  We were across the street at another bar but it was way too hott so we came here. (excellent choice!)

Drink prices are comparable with everything else in the Mission but the bartender made a mean watermelon mojito.  

The dim lighting and spacious furniture layout make this a great place to socialize with friends.
author: Jac J.

description:
Amen for good friends and good conversation!!

Normally I'm a pretty laid-back kind of girl at restaurants.   I understand the stress of being a food server and I usually tip very well, because I've been there and I did it for a long time.

There isn't much to rave about here.  The service was very poor, our food took forever and when it came, it was more than a tad under temperature.  The coffee is weak and the restaurant is chilly.

Will I go back?  doubt it.
author: Kat M.

description:
I've been to The Liberties twice now, and was disappointed both times.

Service is paint-drying slow, as others have mentioned. Whether it's waiting to order, waiting for your food, or waiting for your bill, expect to wait - and sometimes it seems like the staff actively avoids you. They're not rude - they're just not there.

The food was decent, but sometimes disappointing - I ordered a side of toast this morning with my omelette, and was given a grilled hamburger bun. Wasn't really what I was looking for.
author: Brian G.

description: This place freaking Rocks! I have gone here a couple times and have not been disappointed yet! Especially this last time, I was lucky enough to to be able to join in their 10 year anniversary festivities and they definitely know how to throw a party. I have gone to enough yelp parties and other free drink/food events so I definitely know what I am lookin for when I attend them. I generally try never to complain or be picky, since it is free, but I swear there was nothin to even attempt to complain about. The drinks were strong and tasty (some ruby passion drink) and the appetizers were so good. OK, that could be my one complaint, which really isn't a complaint, too much good food, I left way too full and had to keep turning down food I think the beef sliders were my absolute favorite and the Samosas were pretty good too!
author: Rebecca D.

description: First time here. Double Date with My Girlfriend and her Best Friend for dinner. Atmosphere was comfy warm feeling. Staff are friendly. We decide to order a pitcher of Watermelon margarita. It was good you can taste the fruit and alcohol. It will do you good if you just want a little warm feeling. Entrée we had was Steak Tip Sandwich Steak was flavorful and tasty. Price was reasonable for food and drinks. Recommend here if you want to relax watch Sports and eat Comfy Food. Would come back again
author: Gruber T.

description: Great food and drinks to watch a game. I dont know if I would come here otherwise (not my neighborhood and mostly not my crowd). We wanted to watch the game here a few months ago and it was a good place to hang out for the afternoon.
author: Jonathan J.

description:
There's a little text box above this one that says, "You Might Also Consider-" 

No. You wouldn't. 

"But what about the eclectic bar crowd that you find at J. Random Bar down the -"

No. Stop. You're losing focus. Stay with me. Ignore the box above; the box is wrong. Jerry is right. 

Jerry is the guy who works at Liberties. I say, "the guy", because I've honestly never been there when he wasn't completely busting his ass to get the drinks out. Jerry is excellent people. Ask him what's good and he's incapable of lying to you. You'll have to work your way through an impenetrable Irish brogue to get there, but it's worth it (and decoding Irish gets easier over time). 

The drinks are standard bar & pub beers and cocktails. I really don't know much about what people like in beer, but I know that occasionally there's some imported hard-ish to find Irish whisky behind the bar, and if you ask pretty please with sugar on top and bat your eyes, he'll bust it out for you. 

The food is good; their bangers and mash is delish and their boxty is delish and really it's all pretty good. 

Ignore the box. Listen to Jerry. He knows what you want.
author: Jon G.

description:
I spent a Thursday afternoon at The Liberties Bar & Restaurant and kicked  back a couple of drinks and a shot of Fernet with a friend.  Although the place was empty at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, we enjoyed our time chit-chatting with each other and our friendly bartender Kelly.  Sometimes its just nice to lounge in a quiet atmosphere without the hype and racket of a typical bar.  

The bathrooms are clean and the atmosphere is classy.  If I lived in the Mission I would come here often for a pint or to catch up with friends.
author: reena p.

description: Brunch was delish! Loooved my crab cake benedict and breakfast potatoes, yummm! Twas kind of empty for a Sunday.
author: Dana S.

description:
There's something strange going on when the best thing about an Irish bar is the quesadillas.

Fakey atmoshphere, hit-or-miss service, but an okay place to grab a beer. Mellow neighborhood crowd. Fish 'n' chips are pretty good, soda bread is great, quesadillas are awesome, but most important: there's beer.

For anything else, cross the street and go to Lone Palm.
author: Tim B.

description:
I was CRAVING beer battered fish and chips and didnt feel like going too far so we were recommended this place by the bartender at Irish Bank. The city was pretty empty for a weekend, including this restaurant/pub. I disagree with the other reviews saying the decor is too perfect, but I dont like eating in dirty, grungy places...I have given up on taking pepto as an after dinner drink. 

Food: I thought the food here was very very good...not excellent, but it really hit the spot. The F&C were cooked and seasoned perfectly with the right amount of juicyness and crunch. The coleslaw had horseradish which was a plus for me, but WAYYYYY too much mayo for my liking, which ruined it unfortunately.

Now...here is what ruined the scene for me...the people who go there. UGH...annoying beyond belief. On one side, we had whiney loud chicks from OC, and on the other, bland hippies talking about hustling their brother for $$$. If the place had been busier, it might have been better since I wouldnt have had to endure listening to their conversations (and no I wasnt eavesdropping_) I never wanted to leave a restaurant so fast in my life.
author: susan c.

description:
I hadn't been here in so long I actually forgot how bad the food was. 
Unforgettable, uninteresting, and quite untasty. 

On the other hand, this is a drinker's paradise. It's clean, well-lit, and the kind of place you can go to alone or meet someone when you might actually want to chat instead of shouting at each other.  

Since I last went there they have created a whole line of fancy cocktails, featuring, for example, elderflower blossom cordial and champers. Odd for an Irish pub, you might protest, but somewhere along the way (ok, four years ago, to be exact-- JFC I am getting old), Liberties had a facelift and started making flirty drinks with giddy names and fanciful ingredients. Whatever. Youth springs eternal. 

Oh, and the pours of wine by the glass are extremely respectable. You'd call them in the morning.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
I used to eat here sporadically, as a treat. It has a full bar, lovely atmosphere, and the food is delish (highly recommended: the fish and chips and the burger!) until I started spending a lot of time with a friend who lives a block away. Suddenly, I made friends with Jerry and could tell if we should go in or keep walking depending on which tables were full and knew which cocktails to order from the waitress and which ones to go up to the bar for.

They haven't done me wrong yet, with the exception of Friday and Saturday nights between 10 and 12. Then, we'll sit at a table for what feels like a month waiting for *someone, anyone!* to come and take our orders. But when the food and the booze comes, oh heaven.

I wouldn't order the tapas-type food when they're busy, though, they've got a lot going on and tend to get overloaded. Those Tiger Prawns or Boxtys (Boxties?) aren't gonna taste so good if they've been sitting around waiting for an overworked waiter for too long.
author: Rhiannon C.

description:
Totally 'fake' Irish bar. Everything's brand new and right out of the 'Bennigan and Fuddrucker's' manual on how to make an 'hip restaurant to compete with TGI-Friday's'.  Bores me to tears because I feel like I might as well be in Bakersfield or something. Food's overpriced and unoriginal and same can be said for the uninspired drinks.

Pass.
author: Andrew L.

description: I came here for brunch around 3PM on a Sunday. The place wasn't busy. There were 3 other tables.  Even so, I received the worst service. I ordered a blood mary which took 20 min to receive while I watched the bartender texting on his phone the entire time. Once he decided to make the drink, it took 2 min.  I ordered the traditional Irish breakfast which was mediocre at best. Everything was extremely salty. Half way through my meal I ordered another drink (which took another 20min) and the waitress picked up my plate, even though there was no indication that I was near finished.  The bloody Mary's were decent and it has a welcoming atmosphere, but it doesn't make up for the lacking service.
author: W B.

description: Cottage pie, Irish breakfast, and daily specials are good.  Bloody Mary was delicious.  Overall you will pay a little more eating and drinking here than you would at another bar/pup but it does have outdoor seating that stays sunny for most part of the day.  They have high staff turn over but still nice and friendly.  They take Amex too!
author: K W.

description: I like this place, but the bar doesn't seem to feel very much like a bar.  The whole place gives off the restuarant vibe a lot more than anything else.  Come here and find clean bathrooms and un-sticky floors.  Even for a Saturday night, the place maintains a very mellow crowd and a fair amount of available seats.  The service is somewhat flaky, but the selection of beer is good.  The bartender on Saturday knew how to serve up creative cocktails and a proper (foamy) Guinness.
author: Lisa R.

description:
The staff gets a 4 for being really friendly, the bruschetta and wine get 5s - best bruschetta I've had actually- Italy included.

Went with friends the other night and was reminded I'd been here on a date or two a long while back-- one of the girls ordered the shepherd's pie- which I had had and remembered as being really really good in the days when I used to eat meat. I wonder if they cover it in the mashed potatoes so the shepherds don't have to feel bad about eating it in front of the sheep?

I agree with the other reviewers- the irish accents are definitely sexy- not as great at Aussies and Kiwis in my book-- but still devilishly charming!

But the wait-- oh, the wait for pretty much anything is interminable- way way way too long especially when the whole table was ordering small plates and drinks. Still- a good place to go for drinks and a quick bite- would give them the 3.5 if I could- and will continue to head there when I'm in the neighborhood.....and have some time.
author: Keri B.

description:
Lone palm was way too crowded so we walked across the street to Liberty.

We hung around just drinking a couple of drinks for about two hours and never got haggled by the servers, we were able to hear what each other was saying, and they have a fun collection of mixed drinks.
author: Lindsay D.

description:
Food is ok.
Beer is ok.
Space is ok.
Parking sucks.
Drinks are ok.

I'll go with a 3 star.  Why go here when you are so close to the Palm?
author: Thadd L.

description:
If you are just looking for a pint and a quick bite to eat, why not go to the Liberties?
My writing group meets here sometimes and it is a great place for us. Friendly and attentive staff (but not  overly so), good drinks selections, clean and quiet.
We shared some appetizers last time and they were pretty tasty.
Plus, they did not rush us out the door or try to encourage us to finish up.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I go to this place for well-mixed Manhattans, fluffy eggs (at brunch time), and conversation-friendly noise levels.  This place is really underrated.

If you find yourself in the Mission at night and want to go somewhere for a pint where you can get a seat and hear your friends speak, Liberties is for you.

If you are looking for a solid brunch and don't want to stand in line at Boogaloo's, come here and you will be pleasantly surprised.
author: Paul B.

description: Today we learned that The Liberties does brunch.  We had a tasty omelet with avocado, Irish bacon, and cheese with a nice green salad and quesadillas stuffed with cheese and Irish sausage, also with a salad.  For $9 each, they were pretty good.  On the downside, we each had a "large" orange juice, which ended up being about 8 oz of slightly tart juice for $4.50 apiece.  That was maybe not quite as lovely.
author: Angela B.

description:
First visit with workers from a local tech company: Great fries, great service, good drinks.

Second visit with lifelong residents of the MIssion: MOLD ON THE BREAD, SOGGY (???) FRIES, awful, rude service, extremely weak drinks.


Liberties doesnt pass the 'class' test. I.e. it has none.
author: Currently A.

description: Game 1 World Series Rangers @ Giants.  Front room - packed.  Back room - seat saved with my name on it.  Ordered happy hour food specials and Stella on tap.  Munched on calamari, fish tacos, chicken quesadilla and fries.  All yummy.  Only suspect issue - happy hour portions came out smaller than regular priced items (kinda takes away from the whole getting a deal feel).  Service was good and the crowd was friendly.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come again but will def stop by if I am in the hood and hungry when all the other places are closed - they serve food until 1 AM.
author: Amireh G.

description:
They have really good Nieman Ranch burgers.  

This is a good place to go if you want to be sort of in the Mission but you don't want to feel like you're in the Mission.  You're borderline Noe, borderline Irish.

It's solid.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
3.5 stars from me.

I have been to The Liberties twice.  Once for dinner and once for a mid-afternoon snack.

My dinner was good and so was my drink.  The service was friendly, minus them re-seating us toward the very end of our dinner because the party that had reserved tables were late.  It was pretty noisy in there because there was a game on, so if you're looking for a quiet dinner on the weekend, this is definitely not the place for you.  But if you feel like having a beer with some friends and watching the game - it's your place!

I was really surprised to see that they have a late night menu AND a student menu.  Big plus in my book.  I went in there for a bagel and a hot toddy during the late afternoon one day and both the food and drink tasted kind of funny.  I think I'll be ordering something else next time.  The upside to being there in the afternoon was that it was almost empty except for the wait staff and one or two patrons.  

I look forward to eating outside for breakfast some morning soon, or maybe going in for an item off of their late night menu.

To sum up: the food is good, but not great.  They have a decent selection of items and a nice place to sit outside.  The restaurant is a little chilly, so bring a coat.  If you like sports, seat yourself at the bar, grab a drink and enjoy!

**Edited**
We ate outside this weekend and learned that, in order to get an alcoholic beverage while seated outdoors, you need to order food.
Also, some of the tables are pretty wobbly, so make sure you you have something to put under the legs!
author: Heather S.

description: Man, I agree with the reviews that this place is going downhill. The service is great, but the management needs some serious help. Any place that treats their staff like shit does not deserve my money. Sorry Liberties, you guys were great! But I can't support assholes.
author: John K.

description:
-1, if possible.

After having impeccable service at Orson the night before, we followed up the next day with a visit to The Liberties.

Everything started off fine.  Connor was a good server he was personable and funny, and left us to ourselves to converse. This is when The Liberties took the liberty to mess it all up.

Hostess," We are going to move you to another table."

(Note:  We were moved from the dining room to the bar, from a nice quite comfy table to a loud and very uncomfortable table that every time to try an cut a piece of food it moved)

Hostess: "Someone has reserved this table."

(We had enjoyed a drink, and had been waiting for our for food the past twenty minutes at the table)

The Hostess or the manager never apologized, never offered a drink on the house, nothing.

To our surprise, NO ONE EVER SAT AT THE TABLE.  IT REMAINED EMPTY FOR THE REST OF OUR CRAPPY MEAL.

Take the liberty to check out any of the other wonderful restaurants in the area and pass on The Liberties.
author: Joel M.

description: those were not buffalo wings. that was teriyaki sauce.  2 stars strictly based on beer and outdoor seating, mellow vibe. i sooooooooooo wish the food was better.
author: Best M.

description:
Somewhere back there, not too far, I have some Irish predecessors (presumably turned convict and sent in disgrace to my birthplace, the land of kangaroos and Fosters) who passed down through the generations a love for potatoes, dark beers and a pub ambiance.
Hence, my love for The Liberties.
Not only do the fish and chips help ward away potential homesickness, they are amazing - perfectly battered, flaky white fish and crispy amazing fries.  They serve food late, there's always people sitting at the bar meditating over a pint and some good conversation, and the tvs play sports mutedly above the bar.  There's a good selection of beers on tap, and the girls behind the bar can make a pretty decent martini.
My favorite thing about The Liberties though, is brunch.  The best Bloody Mary I have found in the Mission (although I haven't yet sampled the infamous Zeitgeist version), and a menu boasting a full Irish breakfast (complete with Heinz baked beans - so good) and my favorite, the boxty potato pancake with smoked salmon and sour cream.
My boyfriend and I came here on one of our first dates and make it back a couple times a month and it's consistently great.
author: Jane F.

description:
Worst Irish breakfast EVER, and I lived in the UK! Make that worst breakfast in SF ever! Pretty much inedible. And the bitches are cheap too. A basic part of big breakfast is baked beans, but this place charges over $2 bucks for them- on the side! Service was slow to non-existent.

On the plus side, the bartenders are solid and entertaining, the drinks are good, and they have DSL. They should dump the morning food and stick to a liquid diet w/ late night chips.
author: Krismet C.

description:
Lame, lame, lame!!

Slow service...after about 30 minutes on a slow-ish night, I actually had to walk over to the bar to ask if the server had put our order in.  He said he was just about to!  Are you kidding me???

When the food finally came, it was good - but it's tough to mess up crab cakes, and I was so starving at that point that I would gladly have noshed on cardboard.  Oh, and he never came back to see if we wanted another round - and we absolutely did!!

My philosophy group meets there once a month, so I'll be tortured again tomorrow...wish me luck!  I'll be sure not to arrive hungry.
author: Madeleine K.

description:
So I really enjoy this place, the walls are a dark dark green and the decor really makes the place cozy.
The food is excelent; the Steak is very tender, and the Cottage Pie is a decent example of traditional fare.
The Potato Pancake appetizer, and the mashed potatoes are a must, you will not regret either; this place really does a spud justice.

They also have my favorite gin, so they get several bonus points just for that.

However, the service sometimes is slow, but it is usually friendly, and something that can potentially be overlooked.
author: Anton M.

description:
I went here last Sunday for a drink with a friend. I wanted to sit outside but they don't have a bar license, which means you have to order food to drink alcohol outside. We sat inside by the window and the palace was not crowded at all. The bartender was nice and the menu looked pretty good. I would definitely go here again. I think it is a great place for brunch, especially on a sunny day.

I will revise my review after I have a meal here. For now the 3 stars are for the drink and atmosphere.
author: E P.

description: Terrific happy hour! Mon- Fri. 2to7. Great sliders,tacos and more.deals on beer and house cocktail.....relax its happy hour!
author: James B.

description: I really liked this place.  Came here on a Friday night to start out with drinks and it had a really atmosphere, very chill and friendly.  I got a pomegranate mojito which was tangy and the mint perfectly muddled.   I would recommend getting a drink from the bar instead of waiting for someone to come to your table.  Definitely will be one of my new stomping grounds.
author: Beth V.

description: All around good pub, good quality food at a good price. Free of too many mission douchebags, an oasis.
author: G. John E.

description: I really don't get why this place isn't more popular. So many good things to say. In a city where outdoor seating is a rarity, The Liberties has plenty of it. You have to order some food with your yummy draft Lagunitas IPA, but that's fine when their fries, calamari, and samosas are so good.
author: Amy L.

description:
What more could one want than to have a watering hole within walking distance that serves food LATE! Good beer and booze selection, with a menu that steps up from basic pub fare. I really recommend anything with Irish Bacon.

Not the most inexpensive place to go, but being able to eat your food at the bar (and not worry about hygiene) is a lovely thing.
author: Julia P.

description:
I go to this place so often, I can't believe I haven't reviewed it yet. It's not much of a place really, if you want special vibes or great drinks or fun bartenders or interesting drunks. It's usually noisy at dinner, and then people file out and a few regulars are left, usually outnumbered by the staff.

I like it because it's quiet and I can sit by the window and enjoy the view while I drink a Guiness, or a scotch on the rocks. It suits my contemplative mood, and it's open every night till 2am, and the kitchen's available till 10:30 which isn't half bad. And it's in my neighborhood. The staff is friendly, if a little distracted.
author: Sameer S.

description:
After many just meh meals here, I finally found a dish that totally hits the spot.  Their chicken curry on top of french fries.  The curry has a very sweet flavor and there a generous portion of chopped up chicken peas, green beans on top of very nicely cooked french fries...  I've tried the poutine at the Salt House...  the curry at Liberties, while different, was much more satisfying.
Service here though can be quite hit or miss...  even when it's slow in there, the waiters seem distracted and a little absent.
author: Dan G.

description:
Blah.  This review is for the BREAKFAST ONLY!
I decided to try this place because I figured it would be A LOT like the Phoenix.
No dice.
The space was very nice.  There is seating in the back which is where we chose to sit.  
My friend ordered the chicken curry and I ordered the crab cake benedict.  It wasn't very tasty and the crab cakes were the exact same ones I ordered at the Woodhouse Fish Company.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/woodhouse-fish-company-san-francisco#hrid:ZHjmRjErUfw8f8psqYZPnw
I always order my benedicts with a side of French fries with mayo and ranch.  They didn't have ranch here, but bleu cheese.  The bleu cheese dressing had onions in it, which I thought was odd.
I tried a bite of the chicken curry, and the chicken was very tender and nice but the curry tasted like it was made from a mix.  It was a big bowl of sludge.  Not too good to look at.
All in all, I don't think that I will be coming back here any time soon for breakfast.  However, the rest of the menu seemed promising.  I would definitely be back here to booze and the people who work here were very attentive!
author: Meh M.

description: fantastic happy hour menu!  a good selection of beers, cocktails and bar snacks and add $2 taco tuesdays with their superb mussels and fries -- gah i'm a fan and i'm already thinking about my next visit.
author: Karen N.

description: A classy move in this new age of food critiquing is when the owner messages you after an okay review and offers a remedy. I'm appreciated, thank you.
author: Vien T.

description: This is a great standby lowkey place in the neighborhood where i know that I can get a pint and see some football (of the euro persuasion) as well as tasty fish and chips, steak and kidney pies or just a simple pub burger with sweet potato fries. i love that they have food service til1. it's FAB!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Really awful food. It's hard to find a bar in the Mission where you can watch the occassional sports bar. This bar has plenty of tvs, which is nice. But the food is inedible with few vegetarian options. The greyhound is good though.
author: arielle r.

description:
BOOOOOO!!!

The owner of this place needs to get a clue. This place has SOOO much potential. Very cool atmosphere, terrible service, overpriced and umm the food, yuck!!!

I am positive this place would be great and packed all day if they spent some time on a classic pub menu and a few good servers. An advertised happy hour would help too.

Let me know when I should come back.
author: Kara S.

description:
A bit strange inside - it's dark and cavernous but with big screen TVs all over.  Like a mix of a pub and a Sports Bar.  

It's simple bar food and really nothing special, but for a price that borders a decent restaurant.  The cocktails on the menu are girlier than 80s dance music.  Lots of fruity vodka drinks and all that.  I ordered a Manhattan and it was made with just a splash of vermouth, which to me is not knowing how to make a Manhattan.

I wouldn't call it a bad place, but it is too expensive and I won't go again.
author: Jeff R.

description: Average food with a friendly clean bar.   Quieter than the typical iteration of the Irish pub, making it more pleasant for certain experiences and less convivial for others.
author: Patrick B.

description: I love this place. One of my closest friends lived around the corner and eventually started working behind the bar learning the trade. The food is above average, especially for bar fare. Prices are good and the drinks are always top notch. The real selling point is the people. First, the staff are fantastic. Some of the nicest people you'll ever meet. Secondly, the patrons are always a pretty mixed group. On a number of occasions I've struck up random conversations with people around me. I always leave this place with a good feeling!
author: Morgan A.

description: This review is for world cup 2010 season US versus Algeria. Waitress: Why couldn't you just change the tv in the back to the US game? There were hardly any englishmen and there was lots of seating in the back. The atmosphere although, was quite impressive for a soccer match in the US I felt like i was watching Man-U and Chelsea going at it, sans the hooliganism. The menu is very enticing lots of breakfast options to choos from and they repeat any morning games in the afternoon for those of you who start late.
author: Jim L.

description:
2.5

2 stars for serving food late at night and half a star for the fries. 
When that is all there is to say about a place . . . that's about all it deserves.
author: Jen A.

description:
Okay folks enough with the high scoring!  This place sucks.  My boyfriend and I went to have breakfast at the Liberties Bar and Restaurant and were expecting some phenomenal drinks and food but boy were we mistaken.  First of all the Spicy Bloody Mary taste awful.  It is made with Kettle One and basically tomato juice.  No flavor.  And no alcohol taste.  My boyfriend who I have to say really never complains actually spoke up about his food.  He ordered the Irish Breakfast which consisted of; eggs, blood pudding, sausage, beans, and potatoes.  The cost of the place was $11.95.  The eggs were raw in the middle, the beans were canned and disgusting, blood pudding was worth while, and the sausage was not Irish sausage at all.  More like cheap Farmer Johns.  The Irish bacon was just a piece if regular bacon.  The potatoes were red potatoes with a few green onions.  Terrible.  No bread.  My boyfriend is 5th generation native Irish San Franciscan and has lived in this area his whole life, he now knows why he has never came to this place for breakfast or brunch.
Lets get to my order: THE CORNED BEEF HASH and eggs.  Basically canned corned beef with flavorless potatoes and one egg.  For the price of $8.95.  The menu stated it came with a spicy horseradish sauce which was just plain cocktail sauce.  HMMMMMMMM.  Not at all good.  I was really shocked that this facility would be serving canned items.
    I do not blame that Latino cooks in the kitchen, for the lack of poor food.  I blame the owners who allow such crappy food to go out.  The bill came to $43.00.  We are not cheap people and would have chosen to spend $43.00 on breakfast at some place much more flavorful that this establishment.  This is a nightmare.
author: Mar M.

description: Terrible service and drinks...ordered food and waited over 30 minutes for drinks and after nearly 70 minutes with no food in sight all four of us got up and left...not worth your time or effort...no apologies from the bartender who suggested if we had made a reservation that maybe things would have turned out better...we were a group of 4...and the 3rd group of people in the place arriving a bit after 5p...by 6:20p...noticing that others around us who arrived later had their food...we left and enjoyed a wonderful dinner and drinks just down the street.
author: Sabina N.

description: The food tastes good but the value was bad I ordered the $11 Irish breakfast and found it lacking. It contained hash browns, one sausage, two very thinly sliced pieces of Irish bacon (basically one good piece between the two of them), a slice of white pudding about the size of a quarter, a slice of black pudding a little bigger, and two of the smallest eggs I've ever seen (honestly it may have been one egg with two tiny yolks). The breakfast didn't even come with any kind of bread. The service was slooooow, the place wasn't even one third full and the staff seemed swamped. I will not be returning for breakfast.
author: Manny F.

description: The Liberties is a clean, lovely little place with a relaxed vibe. The service here is always EXCELLENT, especially when Laura is working. I also really love that the kitchen is open until 1:00 A.M 7 days a week.....so when I'm feeling like good drink and a snack I can come here and enjoy some sweet potato fries or a potato pancake. What really won me over is that The Liberties makes ice cream cocktails!!! I got a drink with vanilla ice cream, Bailey's and Irish whiskey...blended and topped with whipped cream and chocolate sauce! Holy S! I cannot wait to go back for another one.
author: Emily S.

description: As a quaint pub, this little ditty does the trick, but without blowing your skirt up too high.  The food passes UK muster as much as it can, the waiter with the authentic Irish accent doesn't hurt either.  Their brunch menu looks best, though I haven't tried it.  The bloody mary, I do know, is a good one.  I've observed this is a good place if you want to grab a drink by yourself, hang and watch a game or read a book.  You can do that here and it's totally cool.
author: e w.

description: Worst service I've ever had in the city.  The atmosphere itself is great.  I love bars in the mission in general.  But the hostesses and servers just ruined it.  They were snobby, rude and unaccommodating.  And when we wanted to get our bill, we couldn't get anyone to help us for 30 mins.  We asked a hostess for it and she merely redirected us to our server who was no where to be seen.
author: Melissa M.

description: Great place to grab a drink with friends - think of it as an Irish bar with a tinge more atmosphere.  Love the location in Noe Valley, near the Mission.  On weeknights is a great place to hang out with friends and snag the back room for some apps and drinks.
author: Emily W.

description: Good neighborhood pub to grab a drink at, after dinner (mainly due to the mellow ambiance). Excellent mudslides - if you're into that sort of thing (i.e. dessert) ;) Service was a bit stand-off-ish.
author: Sally M.

description: really cute place. stopped here for a quick drink with a friend. they have a nice menu of specialty cocktails....yum! i ordered the pomegranate mojito- it was the perfect blend of mojito with enough pomegranate to add a little kick. the cocktails were $8-10. the food looked really good too. they also have a pretty awesome HH menu...i'll have to come back and check it out sometime. =)
author: Linda N.

description: Okay. Had an unremarkable dinner here - not bad but nothing special. Good location - if I lived within a couple of blocks I'd probably stop in for a pint of Guinness every so often, but wouldn't go out of my way to come here
author: Karsten P.

description: Met a first-time date here and had a late lunch on a recent Saturday.  We sat at a table facing the street window just off the busy dark-wood bar, and were able to have a conversation without yelling.  The service (cute waitress BTW) was very fast. And the food.  I was impressed by the savory bread pudding with a red wine reduction sauce that was to die for.  I do recommend this place.  As for the Internet date well, let's just say it was strange.  Can't recommend that.  But I'll go back to Libertines for the food and perhaps a draft.
author: David H.

description:
After my father's birthday dinner at Poggio, I headed back into the city to meet Jason for drinks. We decided upon The Liberties on Guerrero because it wasn't nearly as crowded as The Lone Palm. Or at least that's what Jason claimed. I think he merely sensed action at the Liberties. I arrived to find him seated at a table, my red wine already waiting for me. As I sat down, he leaned in and said, "I think there was almost a fight."
"No shit? Between who?" 
Jason explained that when he arrived and ordered our drinks, a gentleman at the bar began chatting Jason up and introduced himself as "Reggie." Apparently, Reggie had just exchanged less than kind words with a white-trash looking fellow wearing a construction company t-shirt and basketball shorts. White trash was accompanied by another hooligan and 2 scantily clad young ladies who fashion themselves the poor man's Paris and Nicky Hilton. In Reggie's corner was his brother, a flawlessly dressed fellow who bore a striking resemblance to Mos Def, right down to the pashmina, hat and designer trench coat. 
Jason and I got to talking about bar fights, Jason's biggest brawl being when he pulled an drunk Asian lady off his fraternity brother. The whole time we're talking, Jason keeps looking at white trash, going "I know that guy. I swear I know that guy." 
Finally, it hits him. "It's Kenny! It's Kenny. I know him. I hired him for a kitchen remodel! Oh my god, I totally know him. That's Kenny. He's a complete asshole."
It is literally exactly at this point that Reggie and Kenny dive at each other, the melee working itself to the back of the bar and behind some wall. A crowd forms as Jason and I crane our necks to catch every inch of this fabulous fracas. Suddenly, Reggie, as if on a Slip N' Slide, flies spread eagle on his belly from behind the wall until he lands under the bar. Mos Def enthusiastically joins the rumble as Kenny's dates remain blissfully oblivious at the other end of the room, deep in a conversation about flavored lip gloss or Lindsey Lohan's bangs. 

It was a decent fight, involving lots of screaming Irish women, people running back and forth through the bar and grunted unintelligible expletives. In all honesty, bar fights make me nervous. I'm convinced that someone will suddenly break a barstool over my head or find a way to drag me into the action I want nothing to do with. But Kenny and his crew where kicked out, the bar erupting into thunderous applause as they left. 
I went to get more drinks as Jason got the scoop from a gal named Sarah who seemed to know the gory details of the dispute. Reggie, as I soon found out, takes it upon himself to say hello to anyone who approaches the bar, and Kenny, actively maintaining the white trash stereotype, somehow took this to be a homosexual come-on. 
Cue fisticuffs...
author: Beth S.

description: Kind of dark and loud, but hey, it's supposed to be Irish. Not really my thing, but a great place in its genre. Prices are reasonable, the food looked remarkably authentic for British bar food (but I can't judge it because I didn't order any food).
author: Alexander G.

description: I've been here a number of times and sad to say, it's hit or miss.  They tend to get overwhelmed when it gets more than 1/2-full and you can wait a looonnnggg time for any attention, let alone your food/drink.  When you're here with little ones, bring them a snack - seriously - I've had (and observed) a few meltdowns by tired and hungry little ones.  That being said, the place has charm and when they're "on", you definitely want to come back, in spite of it being a tad pricey for what you get...I'd still recommend it though!
author: Rich N.

description: Perfectly nice Irish pub. Not really sure why everyone's complaining that it's not really "authentic." (The Irish have opened pubs in the last 20 years after all, but whatever.) My beer was cold, my burger was tasty, and it was cozy and quiet on a Monday night. Plus my waiter had an accent and reeked of cigarettes. How's that for authentic?
author: Arwen O.

description: Living in the Mission is a nightmare on the weekends if you don't like short-distance screaming and arm wrestling for tables. My friends and I are always looking for a nice quiet place where we can sit down, have some drinks, and hold lengthy and heated debates over several political current events and who at the next table we would rather sleep with. The crowd mostly 30s, pleasantly nondescript, reasonably attractive. Cocktails can be weak (to my taste) depending on the bartender.
author: Caitlin P.

description: Why do people go to a bar and complain about the food anyway? When you are old and boring, and your friends are old and boring and live in Noe Valley, then this will be a good place for a beer.
author: Amy E.

description: The burger is the best thing on the menu, the rest of the food is mediocre.  I like the waitstaff, however, I have witnessed the owner being horribly rude and demeaning to one of her employees a few months ago, it was shocking.  Not only should people not treat their employees like this, but to do it in front of customers?  Honestly, spend your money elsewhere.  I will not be returning and supporting her business.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Originally I really liked the atmosphere, the spaciousness and light of the place, and the fact that folks of all ages and types seemed comfortable there. Then I realized over time that the food just wasn't getting better and the portions were generally small. The clincher was recently when we had to wait about 45 minutes for a simple brunch order to be served even though there were only three other tables seated at the time. After half an hour bread was brought to the table, but we had to ask time and time again for refills on the drinks. No discounts were given on the tab and nothing was offered as a gesture of good will for the abysmal service. I am sure that it remains a great place for brew and chat, but I would stay away from the dining.

Update: after staying away for a few years because of the above-stated bad experiences, we decided to give it another try. We sat outside as it was a pleasant autumn evening. That was the first mistake. The intersection of Guerrero and 22nd is a disaster: cars honking at each other like crazy, people screaming, cars almost running over pedestrians, etc. Then there are all the smokers who sit outside.
